Description: Terracotta circular bread-stamp. A circular bread-stamp, with applied truncated conical grip on the centre back. It has an incuse pattern: within a band of angle-tipped tongues and a narrow simple wreath, is the frontal mask of a bull, with looped ribbons falling from a fillet across the forehead, and a four-petalled rosette between the horns. Made by pressing over a modelled form. Micaceous red Nile silt, with a brown surface on the back.
Curator's comments: BM Terracotta IV The bull may be an Apis Bull, but does not have a sun-disc; the rosette may be regarded as a sun-disc, but there are other sacred bulls, or he may be garlanded for sacrifice. Damaged on one side. Comparanda. Near: Besques 1992: no. D/E 4549, from Kom Afrin in the Delta, dated third to second century bc; Pagenstecher 1913: pl. l:3 = Kater-Sibbes and Vermaseren 1975: figs 48 and 95. Not unlike: LIMC ii (2): pl. 176:9, from Memphis; Pagenstecher 1913: pl. xlix:11 = Kater-Sibbes and Vermaseren 1975: fig. 96.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3317)
Acquisition name: Transferred from: Victoria and Albert Museum
Previous owner: Previous owner/ex-collection: Dr W L Hildburgh
